Hi,

Although I haven't tried NEAT on the mountain car problem, I'd like to=

comment that it can be solved without having any hidden nodes in the
contr=
oller (at least the standard version of the problem). I've tried that
by ev=
olving a policy (not a value function) using (1+1)-CMA-ES and noticed
that =
solutions are found very quickly.

Best,
Vassilis

 first possibility I thought is the weak ability of the initial
> populatio=
n, since there are no hidden nodes, the neural network can not
> approximat=
e the value function well. In my experiment, it can not achieve
> the top a=
fter 10000 steps.
> Another reason I considered is the initial weights of t=
he neural network,

mall

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hi,<div><br></div><div style>Although I haven't tried =

lved without having any hidden nodes in the controller (at least the standa=

p>Hi, everyone, I have a problem about neat.<br>
I applied NEAT to the moun=
tain car problem, and I found the result is bad. I want to find out why.<br=
>
Here are some possilbility I am thinking of. Can anyone give me any hints=
 and comments.<br>
The first possibility I thought is the weak ability of t=
he initial population, since there are no hidden nodes, the neural network =
can not approximate the value function well. In my experiment, it can not a=
chieve the top after 10000 steps. <br>

Another reason I considered is the =
initial weights of the neural network, learning rate and so on, these param=
eters should be set carefully, but it takes me a long time, and I haven&#39=
;t found a better setting.<br>
I also think the mutation rate is an importa=
nt factor.If I set a small mutation rate, it may take a longer time to envo=
lve. If I set a bigger value, does this lead to divergence?<br>
<br>
Any fe=
edback is appreciated.<br>
<br>
</p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=
=3D"color:#fff;min-height:0"></div></div></blockquote></div></div></div>
